items.title: You need to listen to these Christmas deep cuts
items.author: Terrence O’Brien
items.summary: - Ten non-obvious Christmas tracks spanning moods from downbeat to space-disco to zen synths.\n- Featured artists include Tom Waits, Lindstrøm, Björk, 100 gecs, Fucked Up, TMBG, Low, Magnetic Fields, Sharon Jones & The Dap-Kings.\n- The piece aims to broaden the holiday playlist with inventive, genre-hopping takes.

items.title: The 35 best gifts that your teen will actually use
items.author: Sheena Vasani

items.title: Job killer
items.author: May Jeong
items.summary: - Adaptation of Westlake's The Ax follows Man-su after a layoff as he targets rivals for a job, mixing dark humor with capitalism critique.\n- The Verge emphasizes careful world-building—props, space, and Easter eggs—and notes an AI turn added during development.\n- Jeong's piece highlights Park's resilience, a late-2025 release, and his advice to filmmakers to seek an authentic voice.

items.title: The best thing I bought this year: The Nintendo Switch 2
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- Switch 2 uses a 7.9-inch, 120Hz 1080p display with upscaling to 4K and high refresh rates, for a bigger handheld/TV feel.
- 256GB internal storage is tight; microSD Express expansion is supported, but cards cost more.
- Tears of the Kingdom runs at 4K/60fps on Switch 2; Mario Kart World is native; price starts at $449.99; Nintendo hints more exclusives and ports to come.

items.title: How AIM taught the internet to chat
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- David Pierce previews a Version History episode on AOL's AIM and its rise as a defining chat app.
- It covers AIM’s inside-AOL origins, its cultural impact, and why executives resisted monetizing it.
- It asks what might have happened if AIM had endured in the social-network era.

items.title: 2025: a year in art on The Verge
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Verge's 2025 art year spans culture, tech, and politics—from DOGE themes to online privacy and dissident surveillance, with a kaleidoscopic gift-guide, a 50-year Saigon hub, and a TikTok-style influencer hub.
- It highlights early Silicon Valley factory abuses, with two women exposing tech accountability; the piece introduces an 'infinite fringe' of racist memes and lists staff credits.
- The package emphasizes handcrafted textures, bold color, psyops visuals, and a DOGE Cerberus portrait, while urging readers to follow topics and authors.

items.title: Humanoid robots are coming. Eventually?
items.author: Robert Hart
items.summary:
- The Verge's Stepback highlights a global surge in humanoid-robot hype with big investments and demos, but true autonomy remains scarce and many performances are staged or teleoperated.
- Falling prices, real-world data collection (cameras and sensors) and synthetic data spur progress, yet critics warn of a data-driven bubble and few justifiable use cases.
- China's embodied AI push and events like World Humanoid Robot Games signal broad interest, but hardware limits and reliance on teleoperation temper expectations.

items.title: Our favorite stuff of 2025
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- Year-end Installer edition catalogs 2025 favorites (Enshittification; Sony WH-1000XM6; Switch 2; Claude Code; Antinote Mac; The Studio; Echo Dot Max; Hue Essentials; Good Hang; Puzzmo) and Kottke homescreen. 
- Homescreen habits favor stock Apple apps; crowd picks include Keychron Q1 HE, AirPods Pro, Android handhelds, Sun Eater, D&D Daddies, Vision Pro. 
- Pierce closes with thanks, 2026 plans, and themes like malleable software, mall Santas, phone bans, and reader-driven projects.

items.title: The Verge’s 2025 holiday gift guide
items.author: Verge Staff

items.title: Sony’s XM5 headphones and the latest Kindle round out this week’s best deals
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- Sony WH-1000XM5 are $248 on Amazon with a free WF-C700N; 30h playback with ANC, lightweight design, eight mics for calls.
- Kindle 11th-gen is $89.99 (ad-supported) with 6" E Ink, Bluetooth for Audible, up to six weeks battery; Echo Dot Max is $79.99 with Matter/Thread/Zigbee.
- Winter deals include Hollow Knight: Silksong on Steam ($15.99), Lego Up House ($30.39), and Keychron V1 Max keyboard ($95.99); Steam Winter Sale ongoing.

items.title: The best last-minute Christmas gifts you can grab for under $50
items.author: Cameron Faulkner
items.summary:
- A gift guide of practical ideas under $50, spanning home, kitchen, travel and tech.
- Highlights include silk pillowcases, candle warmers, compact blenders, USB-C hubs, AirTags and portable speakers.
- Emphasizes affordability and versatility with items priced roughly $13–$45 for various recipients.

items.title: The LCD Steam Deck is done
items.author: Terrence O’Brien
items.summary:
- Valve has discontinued the Steam Deck LCD 256GB model; it’s out of production and currently out of stock on the US site.
- The Verge notes the current entry-level Steam Deck is the 512GB OLED model at $549, with no comment from Valve when asked.
- Analysts say AI-driven RAM/storage costs may drive the discontinuation, while the handheld PC market remains competitive and unlikely to yield a cheaper rival.

items.title: Dogpile’s puzzles mix Balatro, Tetris, and a pile of puppies
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Dogpile fuses deckbuilding, match-3 puzzle mechanics, and Balatro-inspired twists with a cute, gravity-driven dog pile.
- Merge puppies into larger breeds on a physics grid, using modifiers and grooming upgrades to boost points and synergy.
- Steam release with a cozy vibe, no microtransactions, and round-altering penalties after failures.

items.title: You can buy your Xbox Ally an official pair of anti-drift joysticks
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary: - Gulikit, with Asus approval, offers official TMR drift-resistant joysticks for Xbox Ally: US$20, UK£20, and €22 for IT/FR/ES, with January release. - They auto-recognize when swapped and calibrate via Armoury Crate; installation is simple: open, swap modules, reassemble; be careful with ribbon cables. - TMR/magnetic sticks avoid wear-prone potentiometers; drift is mainly addressed by recalibration rather than component wear.

items.title: Friend slop made co-op gaming goofier than ever in 2025
items.author: Stevie Bonifield
items.summary:
- Defines friend slop as humor-first indie co-op games meant to be played with friends, usually under $20, with proximity voice chat and goofy physics.
- Notable titles this year include REPO, Peak, Guilty as Sock!, Lockdown Protocol, Mage Arena, emphasizing shared misadventure over deep story.
- Elden Ring Nightreign is a larger, skill-demanding contrast, while the trend centers on accessibility, affordability, and social play.

items.title: Rivian’s AI pivot is about more than chasing Tesla
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Rivian unveils an end-to-end autonomy push: own AI chips, Gen 2 sensor suite, and a hands-free driving plan with Autonomy Plus.
- Gen 3 hardware arrives by 2026, lidar later, dual-chip computer (~1600 TOPS), two steering modes, and partnerships to enable Level 4.
- Rivian aims for public-market comparables, a $50/month autonomy subscription, and environmental questions as it races Tesla/Waymo.

items.title: The sold-out Nex Playground made my kids laugh and cry
items.author: Sean Hollister

items.title: Want to link from Google’s app store to your app? That’ll be $2–4 per install
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- AB and ECL: ECL would charge $2.85/app or $3.65/game within 24h of an off-Play download, plus 20% IAP and 10% subs; AB: 25% IAP and 10% subs (effectively 20% IAP, 5% subs).
- Enrollment requires Google review, a Google API, and 24h reporting; fees not yet collected and reporting not required now, but may later.
- Epic Games backs the deadline but opposes future fees; Jan 22 hearing precedes possible worldwide Google-Epic settlement with lower fees.

items.title: Google is part of Movies Anywhere again
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Google Play and YouTube purchases can once again sync to Movies Anywhere after a brief outage, with re-enabled retailer support.
- Users must reconnect their Google account for purchases to surface in Movies Anywhere; some received an email with a reconnect button.
- The retailer page lists Google and Disney as participating; no official comments yet from Google or Disney.

items.title: Did a publisher’s slip-up reveal smaller Switch 2 cartridges?
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- ININ Games briefly referenced two smaller Switch 2 cartridge sizes, then removed the claim and said there was no official Nintendo announcement.
- ININ will release the physical Switch 2 version with a €10 surcharge; Nintendo did not comment; cost and memory sizes are cited as reasons.
- A Brazilian journalist cited Arc System Works leaks about two formats (64GB cartridge and game-key card); analysts say memory costs influence decisions.

items.title: Gemini isn’t replacing Google Assistant on Android just yet
items.author: Emma Roth
